questions.text: Have you entered your basic personal information (name, SSN, address)?
questions.help_text: This includes your full name, Social Security Number, date of birth, and current mailing address. You'll need your Social Security card and recent mail for this information.

questions.text: What is your filing status?
questions.help_text: Your filing status determines your tax rates, standard deduction, and eligibility for certain credits. Check IRS Publication 501 for details.

questions.text: Do you have dependents (children, relatives) who lived with you?
questions.help_text: Dependents can include children under 19 (or 24 if students), or other qualifying relatives. You'll need their Social Security numbers and relationship to you.

questions.text: How many dependents do you have?
questions.help_text: Count each qualifying child or relative. Make sure you have their full names and Social Security numbers.

questions.text: Did you receive income from employment (W-2 forms)?
questions.help_text: This includes wages, salaries, tips, and other compensation from employers. Check your W-2 forms from all jobs worked this year.

questions.text: How many W-2 forms did you receive?
questions.help_text: Count each employer you worked for. You'll need to enter information from each W-2 form.

questions.text: Did you have self-employment income (freelance, business, gig work)?
questions.help_text: This includes income from freelancing, consulting, rideshare driving, or running your own business. You'll need records of income and business expenses.

questions.text: What type of self-employment income did you have?
questions.help_text: Different types of self-employment may require different forms and have different deduction rules.

questions.text: Did you receive investment income (interest, dividends, capital gains)?
questions.help_text: This includes interest from savings/bonds, dividends from stocks, or profits from selling investments. Check 1099-INT, 1099-DIV, and 1099-B forms.

questions.text: What types of investment income did you receive?
questions.help_text: Different types of investment income are reported on different forms and may have different tax rates.

questions.text: Did you buy, sell, or trade cryptocurrency this year?
questions.help_text: This includes Bitcoin, Ethereum, and other digital currencies. You'll need records of all transactions including dates, amounts, and values.
Cryptocurrency transactions must be reported as capital gains/losses. Keep detailed records of all buys, sells, and trades.

questions.text: Did you receive retirement income (pensions, IRAs, Social Security)?
questions.help_text: This includes pensions, 401(k) distributions, IRA withdrawals, and Social Security benefits. Check Forms SSA-1099 and 1099-R.

questions.text: Did you have foreign income or own foreign bank accounts?
questions.help_text: This includes income earned abroad or accounts in foreign banks. Foreign accounts over $10,000 must be reported on FBAR.

questions.text: Did any foreign bank account have a balance over $10,000 at any time?
questions.help_text: If yes, you must file FBAR (FinCEN Form 114) in addition to your tax return. This is required even if you don't owe additional tax.

questions.text: Do you want to itemize deductions instead of taking the standard deduction?
questions.help_text: Itemizing allows you to deduct expenses like mortgage interest, state taxes, medical expenses, and charitable donations. Compare with the standard deduction.

questions.text: Which types of itemized deductions do you have?
questions.help_text: Select all that apply. You'll need receipts and records for each type of deduction claimed.

questions.text: Did you work from home or have a home office for business?
questions.help_text: If you used part of your home exclusively for business, you may be able to deduct home office expenses like utilities and internet.

questions.text: Do you have qualifying children under 17 for the Child Tax Credit?
questions.help_text: The Child Tax Credit provides up to $2,000 per qualifying child. Children must be under 17 at year-end and live with you more than half the year.

questions.text: Did you or your dependents pay for college or other higher education?
questions.help_text: You may qualify for education credits like the American Opportunity Credit ($2,500) or Lifetime Learning Credit. You'll need Form 1098-T from the school.

questions.text: Did you make energy-efficient home improvements?
questions.help_text: Credits are available for solar panels, energy-efficient windows, electric vehicles, and other green improvements. Check IRS Publication 570.

questions.text: Based on your income level, do you think you might qualify for the Earned Income Credit?
questions.help_text: The EIC is a refundable credit for low-to-moderate income workers. Maximum credit is $7,430 for 2024. Income limits apply.

questions.text: Are you filing as an estate, trust, or decedent?
questions.help_text: If you're the executor of an estate or trustee of a trust, you'll need to file Form 1041 instead of or in addition to Form 1040.

questions.text: Do you own an interest in a partnership, LLC, or S-Corporation?
questions.help_text: If you received a K-1 form from a business entity, you'll need to report that income on your personal return.

questions.text: Do you need to amend a prior year's tax return?
questions.help_text: If you discovered errors or omissions from a previous return, you can file Form 1040-X to claim a refund or pay additional tax.

questions.text: Did you make quarterly estimated tax payments?
questions.help_text: If you had significant self-employment income or other non-withholding income, you may have made quarterly payments using Form 1040-ES.
